message: I like that someone's trying to give the script's a better home, since vim.org is... dated. Still, I feel like we need a site that better categorizes them, with ratings/comments.
Just got an idea for a weekend project...

I've been trying to stick with plugins that I can just add as a git submodule and let pathogen manage. It feels minimal and portable and works well so far. Seems like with a little glue there could be a basic package-management style system more akin to what we're used to with PyPI/apt/CPAN/etc..

Also, I've come to notice people creating Git repositories of their own configurations, enabling pullers to keep their vim configuration updated. Here's mine: https://github.com/oryband/vim I mostly write in Python/HTML/CSS/JS.

I've been keeping my dotfiles in mercurial for a while, but I recently switched to git, mostly so that I can use git submodules to keep all my plugins up to date.  Most of the plugins I use are developed on github anyway, but for the rest, the vim-scripts mirror repos are great. Even if you don't care about tracking the history of your dotfiles, being able to update all of your vim plugins with one command is a pretty killer feature.
@nat mercurial has subrepos which work for that as well...
